comment: It's almost as if somebody has handed to you a Michelin star dish that was underseasoned  - it tastes great, it's got everything, but something's missing, and it shows. Something's missing in this whisky as well, and I can't put my finger on it, but I know it's the difference from one of the best and a dram I'd leave for someone else to enjoy
Dont like. Too peaty. Never buy

2/17 Hook & Ladder. Fruity, sherry, hint of peat.   A bit young but still delicious 
8/17 TWM. Similar to Yamazaki but bit more vertical layer of flavors
A bit harsh. Lots of peat

Oh god, I tried this in Japan and I mostly got burn and bitterness. Yes, it's the bolder, peatier side of Taketsuru, the alcohol is stronger, the bourbon cask is fiercer, there is a bit of sherry in there... But I was essentially appalled by this, despite being a big Nikka fan. Nikka from the Barrel, Taketsuru and even Nikka All Malts and Coffey Grain are ones I'd rather have over this.

On the Nose -Spice, Old Wood, Fresh mint, lemon grass, sea breeze, leather.
On the palate - more spice but not too hot of you let it breathe for 20 minutes or so. Afraid to add a drop of water since it taste so complex and so damn good. You will want to take your time on this one for sure. Good price buy one if you see it before they disappear. Highly recommended after a good meal. Paid like 60

Had this during a business dinner some time back.  Generally, I've disliked NAS Japanese whiskies, just seems to be a shell of it's aged versions.  I"ve not tasted the aged version of MIyagikyo, so fortunately, haven't been jaded (yet).  Nose: floral and summer-y.  Taste:  roasted nuts, mild.  Non-challenging, but so very not complex.  Like a Balvenie...can't do no wrong, but nothing that makes you go 'wow'.  Finish:  quick, mild.  Not a bad NAS version, better than the NAS Yoichi for sure.  Not sure what the price is, but I'd not pay over $50 for it.  You can get better complexity elsewhere for that price (Great King St is the first that comes to mind)

Nose - Buttery, fruity, yellow cake, caramelized pears, waxy golden raisins.
Taste - Fruity, syrupy but crisp sweet, hint of white pepper spice, fresh pears eaten with golden raisins, very faint quickly fading bitter, tiniest hint of campfire smoke.
Finish - Lingering lightly smoky sweet, syrupy golden raisins, which lead me to believe this was aged in a lighter colored sherry, tiny hint of campfire ash.
Score - 79/100
Final Thoughts - On the nose, I don't think you could tell that there was any hint of peat in this malt as the syrupy/waxy sweet dominates. Once it hits the tongue, you're hit with the sensation as if you were at a campsite in the morning making oatmeal with golden raisins & honey with the campfire from last night out, but the smoke still lingers in the air. The finish is like you've finished your oatmeal and you take a deep breath of the crisp autumn air that still has that tiny hint of campfire ash. Overall a decent dram that's very sippable neat but is kind of just light smoke & golden raisin sweet to me. I can see this making a very interesting highball.

Good but the age statements are better,

https://www.change.org/p/bring-back-yoichi-and-miyagikyo-age-statements

This whisky is almost worth the price for the aroma alone. A wonderful combination of pretty sherry fruit and wet peat. Afterwards there are subtle vanilla malt and earthy spices. On the palate the sherry is displayed in the most favorable way. Offering tiny ripe berries, sweet malt, and roasted nuts. The finish gently breathes smoke down your throat like a seductress that is a little more kinky than you thought. Great NAS whisky!

The nose is floral, but somewhat sulphury. The palate has a sweet citrus note, some malted cereal, followed by a touch of aniseed on the finish. Unfortunately, the off-key notes on the nose ruined it for me. Disappointed.

The nose is complex, and though not exactly sherried, it is quite fruity with an underlying layer of nuttiness. The almonds and clove on the palate play very nice here, with the finish continuing and rounding off a great experience. I like it.

Light, fruity, pleasant nose. Some fortified wine notes as well. Velvety on the tongue, with good weight. Surprising but nuanced smokiness, with an undercurrent of malt and white fruits, some mild bitterness up front and a sweet aftertaste. 6/12/17
Fruity, sweet - not as good as the Nikka Pure malt.
Geproefd in Tokyo. Heel lekker. Mild rokerig.
A bit one note, but good.
Really pleasant light smoke that reveals sherry, vanilla and dried fruit! Really good dram!

Enjoyed @ Bourbon Square in Hiroshima
Floral, light, easy to drink, very good
sweet, sherry forward, well developed and smooth, deep flavor, great finish.
Very Decent with breakfast cereals and some mild peat . Highly sippalble
Very sweet, but also a little harsh, more so than the Coffey. Makes me wish they still had an age statement. 88
intensely sweet with just a hint of smoke
Classic entry Japanese whiskey. Balanced, some peat but not overpowering.
Bourbon fan drinking whiskey. It’s just ok for me
Small peat, very smooth, light sweetness
Sherry hints but light. Not impressive but price acceptable when purchasing in Japan. Might try highball with it. /3 or 3.5
Smokey, similar to a scotch but not as full bodied
Flower tea with heavy sherry vibes
Smokey, light and a lot of citrus. Good sherry notes on the nose but not a lot of depth. Easy drink despite a little initial burn.

Another class act from probably the most consistent distillery here in Japan. The age statement versions are now impossible to find. Even the nas version takes some serious hunting down. Miyagikyo is deep, lush, rich, with hints of tropical fruit, dried fruit, a touch grassy, an almond, hazelnut and herbal note, and a decent touch of peat. Lovely stuff.
smoky and with a burn. needs a little water to open up.
Hearty sherry spices with a nice smokiness on the back end
Dulce y calido con final seco. Recuerdo frutal de paso por barrica de mizunara. Nota de frutos secos también presente. Muy bueno

Color: light gold
N: Rancid, cherry, caramel 
P: Peated, stinky, peppery, 
F: Spicy, nutty, flat

I had this whilst on a rare overnighter which meant I was back at my favorite whiskey bar with a couple of mates. Nose was interesting. I got bubblegum scent and on the palate floral and light honey and vanilla. To busy chatting to gather much more but nice dram, one of the better japanese offerings I've had in the price range. 3.5 to 3.75.

Update: Another year another sample. Smells almost like mild mescal. 3.5 I reckon lower range of what i once thought.
Excellent single malt with some smoky notes
Light peat, feels very scotch like. It married the Smokey and sweet floral notes of Japanese whisky

Of the non-age stamped Nikka single malt range, I love this one the most. Great neat, on ice, or slowly dripped with water. Each way of drinking changes the whiskey enough to give you a different experience each time. I'm a big big fan.
Mildly peaty like a smooth scotch. Bitter on the pallet and tarty on the finish.
Am I getting peat on the finish?!?

Nose is powerful.  Has some French toast elements with maple.  Flavor is sweet, but balanced.  Begins with sticky golden fruit notes which end up being consumed by peat and salt.  Finish is almost never ending.  There is such an elegance and purity to these Nikka malts.
Excellent. Nice smoke, vanilla, light oak.

An exceptional NAS Japanese whisky.

Nose: Barnyard, Sherry, Honey, Breath of smoke
Palate: Picking season cherry orchard. 
Finish: Long and light sweetness carried on for minutes after a taste. 

To be most honest, when tasting a friend on it, the finish was still lingering 15~20 minutes after. One of my favorite Japanese whiskys from one of the most consistently excellent distillers.
Straw color. Sweet petals nose. Almond paste and sherry notes. Excellent value.
Sweet and fruity easy to drink

Nose:  Baking spices, brown sugar, and honey, as well as some green apple. Caramel apple anyone?

Palate: Initially some more orchard fruits, especially apple here. More honey in the background as well. Definitely some alcohol burn but it's not overwhelming. A tiny bit of peat coming through towards the end.  Nice oily mouth feel.

Finish: Long and grainy, reminiscent of a nice Irish whisky. Very slight hint of peat lingers, but appropriately subtle.  Very pleasant!

Mild-mannered and citrusy on the nose, with honey and lemons and dates and almost no heat.  There’s some burn in the mouth, though, along with an Irish-like biscuit note.  Long finish of something resembling pasta.  Angular and really refreshing as a change of pace.  I think I like it more than the conventional wisdom would dictate.

Nose - red fruits, honey, vanilla, light pastry crust, a hint of soft younger oak, strawberries.

Taste - banana, vanilla, toasted oak, some cream, and then the funky sherry wine note, very bitter. Miyagikyo brings the funky oak from the sherry really out with youthful spirit note and a lot of vanilla's and some new maker spirit elements. A bit of water seems to bring this one more to life, enhancing the sherry and pushing back some of that youth.  Noticing some light peat notes here as well, I wasn't aware this is peated but if it is not, I'm way off and maybe I'll delete this review, but I'm getting more than a little peat. Perhaps the peat is some of the bitter notes I thought were from the sherry.

This is an interesting effort from Nikka, while I do generally think there's quality here, it's just too young. The peat is not helping with the sherry. Honestly, i'd rather get more of the sweet nikka malt with sherry.

I'm going 1.75 here, same score as the Yoichi though I'm more a peat guy so I'd buy the Yoichi again before this one. Neither are likely to be repeat buys unless I find them a bit more affordable.
Slight peat and nice balance, especially for a whiskey with no age statement. A slight medicinal note. But definitely a good general option

Nose: Grassy and mildly earthy with a lot of citrus notes - lemon zest, orange concentrate, grapefruit - bright citrus rather than sweet and there's a little pineapple as well. A leathery honeyed note creeps in at the sides to keep things interesting. The nose gains substantial complexity and breadth as it opens and when first poured the ethanol is a bit punchy so allow a few minutes for it to develop. A dash of water enhances the nose by bringing out floral notes (lilies, jonquils, honeysuckle). Most elegant and enjoyable.

Palate: Lovely easy arrival. Sweet, rounded, honeyed cereal flavours, almonds and warm spices. Very friendly and there is a pleasant puff of smoke on the palate that emerges a few seconds after the arrival. A little beeswax and vanilla with some berry and sweet white grape notes on the palate. In the late development and finish a distinct milk chocolate flavour is apparent. The texture is excellent and has a creamy density that is very satisfying. Adding a drop of water softens and sweetens the palate.

Finish: Medium/short. Leathery sweet-malt taste with some musky floral and charcoal-like smoke on the aftertaste.

There's a handsome, sweaty farmyard quality to this whisky that is very enjoyable. It's a little like a polite and graceful Japanese version of Ben Nevis or Hazelburn. Adding water is not necessary at all as this is very nice neat, however neither does it do any harm but simply sweetens and lightens the profile.

Tasted from a 30ml sample (thank you Wei). I'm considering adding a bottle to my next whisky order. It's the same price here as Nikka Coffey Malt, and it would be a tough choice between the two.

"Good, just a whisker below Very Good" : 3.75 stars (and it's quite possible that with time to explore a whole bottle I'd raise that to 4 stars).
Fruité, intense, persistant. Vers les fruits jaune, poire et pomme. Très bon. A quand la prochaine bouteille...

Nose: Elegant, sweetness
Palate: Medium body, light smoky comes after, barely sweet.

Jason said to try this
March 2020
Typical Japanese flavor with a slight back taste of smoke. Slight fruity and sweetness that has a distinct earthy flavor.

A total dissapointment. This review is actually for the Miyagikyo Single Malt NAS 45%abv. Good on the nose but completely regular on the palate. 

Bottled at 45%abv

On the nose, Burnt cake crest, Pears, super fresh; Beautiful vanilla. Fondant. Pear juice. Very clean very fresh, Hints of coconut. 

On the palate, super boring. Pepper, 
A little vanilla. Very alcoholic and cerealic.
Maybe a coconut note. Feels cheap. 

Aftertaste is harsh. Cereal /alcoholic. Ginger and a very little hint of chocolate.
Dry overall. 

This whisky feels cheap. Even if it has a decent aroma, the flavor is nothing. Too young and harsh. 55 over 100.
Id buy it again. Tested with Chris aaron at the knick

★★★★
Voici quelque chose à découvrir.
Ce single malt japonais est un délice à découvrir. On retrouve un peu de tout dans ce nectar nippon, mais ce qui me fair tourner la tête c'est sa finition en fût de Xérès qui lui donne ce petit kick épicé qui me plait tant. Une autre belle découverte et en plus, je viens de voir qu'il y en a 12 bouteille à Lomoilou :-)
Sweet floral nose with a little salt and a hint of peat. Light taste. Aromatic. Barley aftertaste. Like it a lot.
Slight burn at end, floral flavor. Mild smoke, mild vanilla notes.

Nikka Whisky is rightfully sought after as they don't have a Whisky in their portfolio that isn't good. Furthermore, whilst not always readily available they can be found with some hunting at a very reasonable SRP. This specific expression from Nikka is one of the 2 single malts they produce (the other being the Yoichi). For me this is truly the crown jewel of the Nikka NAS releases! Why is that? Let's dive in and find out... 

It enters rich and fruity with a burst of apricots, plums and nougat. There is some salt and smoke also present in the background that provides a wonderful compliment. Ripe berries and a hint of seaweed on the mid palate with a long finish that adds oak and dark chocolate to the party. Wood spice lingers on the tongue.

This one is really a proper classic sherried whisky! It's like an old school Glendronach that retains the soul of Nikka. TGIF all and stay safe!

A total dissapointment. This review is actually for the Miyagikyo Single Malt NAS 45%abv. Good on the nose but completely regular on the palate. 

Bottled at 45%abv

On the nose, Burnt cake crest, Pears, super fresh; Beautiful vanilla. Fondant. Pear juice. Very clean very fresh, Hints of coconut. 

On the palate, super boring. Pepper, 
A little vanilla. Very alcoholic and cerealic.
Maybe a coconut note. Feels cheap. 

Aftertaste is harsh. Cereal /alcoholic. Ginger and a very little hint of chocolate.
Dry overall. 

This whisky feels cheap. Even if it has a decent aroma, the flavor is nothing. Too young and harsh. 55 over 100.
Japan proves once again that whenever they start a craft, they elevate it to perfection.
One to persevere with. I wasn't a great fan on first tasting but over the following weeks it really grew on me.
